Package boardifier.model

Class GameElement

java.lang.Object
boardifier.model.GameElement
Direct Known Subclasses:
HeroCard, MovementCard, Pawn, SpriteElement, StaticElement, TextElement
public abstract class GameElement extends Object
abstract class that describes an element of the game, in the largest sense.

It can be the board, a sprite, a background, ... It contains the data needed to manage the state and the behaviour of an element of the game. In order to be taken into account during the game, a GameElement must be put in a GameStage (see GameStage.addElement() ). The best way is to instantiate all game elements needed by a game stage, within the method GameStage.createElements().

Even if this class is not intended to define the visual aspect (i.e. the look), some of the data are directly used to customize the look: the location in space, the visibility, if it is selected, ... Thus, as long as a GameElement is not associated to an ElementLook, it has no representation in the window game. The "normal" way to do that is:*

  • Field Details

    • x

      protected double x

    • y

      protected double y

    • gameStageModel

      protected GameStageModel gameStageModel
      the game stage that owns this element

    • visible

      protected boolean visible
      the visibility of this element

    • selected

      protected boolean selected
      defines if this element is selected or not

    • clickable

      protected boolean clickable
      defines if the element can taken into account when a mouse click occurs on it. If there is a click on the element and clickable is false, then Controller.elementsAt() will not use this element. It is set to true by default.

    • type

      protected int type
      the type of this element.

      It must be a type that is registered in ElementTypes.

    • container

      protected ContainerElement container
      the container element that contains this element.

      It is not mandatory to put an element within a cell of a ContainerElement or its subclasses. It is more useful for board games to trigger some actions when an element is moved from a cell to another one.

    • animation

      protected Animation animation
      the current animation effect associated to this element.

      It is normally null. But if an animation, like moving the element, changing its look, ... is needed, this attribute allows to retrieve the AnimationStep objects that are created all along the animation time.

      See Also:
      • Animation.next()

    • eventQueue

      protected EventQueue eventQueue

    • inContainerOp

      protected boolean inContainerOp

    • GameElement

      public GameElement(GameStageModel gameStageModel)

      It calls the general constructor but with a location at 0,0 and a type set to basic.

      Parameters:

      public GameElement(GameStageModel gameStageModel, int type)
      It calls the general constructor but with a location at 0,0 and the given type.
      Parameters:
      gameStageModel - The game stage that owns this element.
      type - The type of this element. Must be a registered type in ElementTypes

      y - The y location in space
      gameStageModel - The game stage that owns this element.

    • getLocation

      public Coord2D getLocation()
      Returns:
      the current location in space

    • setLocation

      public void setLocation(double x, double y, boolean doEvent)
      Set the new location in space.

      If a look is associated to this element (i.e. look is not null), then the main group of the look is moved to the same location. It implies that the scene will be repainted with the new location of the look.

      Parameters:
      x - The x location in space
      y - The y location in space

    • setLocation

      public void setLocation(double x, double y)

    • relativeMove

      public void relativeMove(double dx, double dy)
      Set the location with a relative move of dx,dy. This method can be used when a sprite with a speed expressed in dx,dy must be moved.
      Parameters:
      dx -
      dy -

    • getGameStage

      public GameStageModel getGameStage()
      Returns:
      The game stage that owns this element

    • isVisible

      public boolean isVisible()
      Returns:
      if the element is visible

    • setVisible

      public void setVisible(boolean visible)
      Set the visibility of the element.

      If a look is associated to this element (i.e. look is not null), then the calls setVisible() on that look. It implies that the scene will be repainted if the visibility of the look changed.

      Parameters:
      visible - pass true to make the element visible, otherwise false

    • isSelected

      public boolean isSelected()
      Returns:
      true if the element is selected, otherwise false

    • toggleSelected

      public void toggleSelected()
      reverse the selected state of the element.

    • select

      public void select()
      Set the element as selected. It calls GameStage.setSelected() in order to update its list of selected elements. If a look is associated to this element (i.e. look is not null), then calls setSelected(true) on that look. It implies that the scene may be repainted if the look is different when selected and unselected.

    • unselect

      public void unselect()
      Set the element as unselected. It calls GameStage.setSelected() in order to update its list of selected elements. If a look is associated to this element (i.e. look is not null), then calls setSelected(true) on that look. It implies that the scene may be repainted if the look is different when selected and unselected.

    • isClickable

      public boolean isClickable()
      get the clickable state.
      Returns:
      true if the element is clickable, otherwise false

    • setClickable

      public void setClickable(boolean clickable)
      Set the element to be clickable, or not.
      Parameters:
      clickable - true if the element must be set as clickable, otherwise false

    • removeFromStage

      public void removeFromStage()
      Remove this element from the current stage.

      It just calls the method that does the job in GameStage. As a recall: instead of really removing the element from the stage and the nodes of its associated look from the scene it just hides the element and move it to un unreachable location.

    • stopAnimation

      public void stopAnimation()
      Allows the element to stop itself its current animation. It can be useful if the element reached a state for which it is necessary to stop the current animation. For example, it could be a sprite that is temporarily animated but the animation must be stopped because of a collision.

    • update

      public void update()
      Update the element. This method will be called at each frame. It can be used to update the location of the element, its state, or any other attribute that is defined in its class.*

    • getModel

      public Model getModel()

    • isInStage

      public boolean isInStage()
